Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Siberian Traps and the end-Permian Extinction: Coincidence and Causality
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project address an important, and unresolved question in Earth evolution, i.e. did the eruption of the Siberian Large Igneous Province (LIP) a.k.a. Siberian Traps cause the Permo-Triassic extinction? In reality there are two questions at the heart of this proposal; what causes flood basalts and do flood basalts cause extinctions? These questions have been the subject of active research for several decades. One of the unique aspects of this project is that both are addressed simultaneously by an international team of experts whose goal is to gain an in-depth understanding of this LIP from its origin to both short-and long-term effects on Earth systems. The PIs will use a large suite of techniques: geochemistry, geothermometry, paleomagnetics, seismology, geodynamics, paleontology, and climate modeling to achieve their goal. Specifically, the PIs will:

> create high-precision eruption time scales for the entire volcanic succession, thus obtaining flux rates;
> quantify the volatile loads of the igneous rocks including lavas, intrusives, and in particular the voluminous tuffs;
> quantify volatile release from country rocks;
> begin to map the crustal and upper-mantle structure beneath the region using existing seismic data and geodynamical modeling;
> study the climatic consequences of sulfur injection and buildup of atmospheric carbon dioxide; and
> continue detailed studies of the end-Permian extinction, using paleontology, stable isotope geochemistry, and geochronology.


Broader Impacts:

The PI team consists of scientists from 7 different countries. A central repository will be created for samples obtained under this project. Information will be maintained on the web and material made available to other scientists. A documentary film producer associated with the National Geographic Corporation will be in the field with the PIs gathering footage for a film about the project. Additional coverage is will be provided through the American Museum of Natural History?s Science Bulletins, short films about current research that are shown at the AMNH and distributed to over 40 science centers and museums around the world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Enormous and geologically rapid eruptions of flood basalts associated with large igneous provinces have long been implicated as drivers of global environmental change leading to ecosystem destabilization and massive die out of living organism in the geologic past. The most severe of these mass extinction ever known, namely the end-Permian extinction, occurred approximately 252 million years ago and appears to have coincided with the voluminous eruption of the Siberian Large Igneous Province (Siberian Traps) in northern Russia. In order to examine the causal relationship between the two events, it is crucial to understand if the massive volcanism began before, coincident with or after the extinction. In the latter case, the volcanism will have to be ruled out as a possible driving mechanism.

The goal of this project was to explore in detail the coincidence between the Siberian Traps volcanism and the end-Permian extinction by establishing accurate and sufficiently precise timelines for the two events.  The mass extinction is best recorded – and most extensively studied – in the Permo-Triassic marine successions of eastern and southern China, a long distance from the flood basalt exposures in Siberia. Here, thin layers of ancient volcanic ash interbedded with fossiliferous marine sedimentary rocks have been dated in order to bracket the extinction horizon and to constrain its precise timing. Small crystals of a uranium-bearing mineral knows as zircon (ZrSiO4) extracted from the ash beds were analyzed by the U-Pb radioisotopic technique to measure the age of magmatic crystallization, eruption of the ash and thus the age of deposition of sedimentary strata that preserve evidence of biologic extinction. In a somewhat similar approach, zircon from the intrusive mafic sills and pyroclastic rocks, as well as mineral perovskite (CaTiO3) from the basaltic lava flows, were analyzed by the high-precision U-Pb dating method to unravel the detailed magmatic history of the Siberian Traps.

The geochronological results of this project indicate that two-third of the total basaltic lava/pyroclastic volume associated with the Siberian Traps erupted within an approximately 300 thousand year interval, before and during the end-Permian mass extinction, which itself occurred within less than 110 thousand years (minimum of 13 thousand years). In addition, extensive emplacement of mafic sills into the supracrustal rocks began concomitant with the extinction and, together with eruption of the remaining lava flows, continued for at least 500 thousand years after the extinction event. In summary, the results of this research are permissive of the Siberian Traps volcanism and the resulting environmental perturbations acting as drivers of the end-Permian mass extinction.

Although synchroneity by itself cannot be taken as proof of causal relationship, rapid injection of large quantities of greenhouse gases (e.g., carbon dioxide) into the atmosphere would most likely cause disruption of the carbon cycle, alter the ocean/atmosphere chemistry and drive climate change with a high potential for severe ecosystem destabilization. Further research facilitated by improved geochronology can shed light on the detailed relationship between magmatism and biotic crisis. The observation that catastrophic extinctions occurred on very short time scales in the geologic past has significant implications for modern-time impact of human activities on the Earth and the role of rapid environmental change in shaping the future of life on the planet.
